{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3658835,"name":"Adam Aptowitz","username":"adama12","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/e8c25b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-20T22:13:15.418Z","cooked":"

Hello! I have an elevator that uses a CANCoder to determine position and velocity. During competition, the elevator seems to jerk up and down during motion. Looking at the log files from the match (Archimedes Qual 97), it seems like the data from the CANcoder doesn’t update for about 0.5 seconds.

We are using a profiled PID controller, specifically a trapezoidal profile. When the data finally updates, the elevator is above the setpoint. The robot applies -33 volts to bring the elevator back down. Then, since the elevator is below the setpoint, it tries to bring the elevator back up in quick succession. This results in the elevator violently jerking up and down.

Why does the CANcoder stop reading values? Could it be a loop overrun or an issue with the encoder itself? I’ve attached the relevant log file below, as well as a link to our GitHub repo.

akit_25-04-18_12-28-18_archimedes_q97.zip (10.6 MB)
https://github.com/steelhawks/Reefscape2025

You’re raising your main thread priority to the RT max of 99, which is likely starving other threads.

Auto Init Overrun Programming
Just as a warning, do not raise your main thread to RT priority without understanding the consequences. By raising the main thread to RT priority 10, you preempt nearly every vendor thread. That means that while your robot code is running, you may not receive new CAN frames (resulting in stale frame warnings and bad odometry), and the enable frame may be delayed (in the worst case causing devices to blip disabled), among other issues. If your loop times are well above 10 ms or you experience l…

I would also recommend updating your Phoenix 6 vendordep to the latest (25.4.0) to pick up some bug fixes.

I would say the thread setting is the most important thing. It makes a very small difference in performance and if you are already reaching high lag before applying that it amplifies it significantly. If the main thread takes all 20ms, then things like CAN or NT can’t update every cycle. AdvantageKit documents this under the TalonFX swerve template docs, if you are curious.
